Shree Bhoga Nandeeshwara Temple, Karnataka

Dedicated to Shiva, The original Temple was built in the 9th century.

The history of the eastern regions of south Karnataka traces to ancient times. They developed under the reign of the Rashtrakuta and Ganga dynasties. By the 8th-century, the Hindu Nolambas – also known as Nolamba-Pallavas – were governing this region for the Rashtrakuta and Ganga dynasties. The reign of Mahendra I (860–895 CE) brought renewed powers and economic prosperity after he defeated the Banas. After the death of Mahendra I, his mother Devalabbarasi came to power assisted by her second son Iriva-Nolamba. She was great patron of arts, used the epithet Nolamba for her sons, and she built the Nolamba-Narayanesvara temple. The style that emerged from these period (850–1000 CE) reflects a synthesis of regional Hindu arts, and is now called the Nolambavadi style.

Early 9th-century inscriptions found near Nandi village refer to a temple for Shiva. However, these inscriptions do not mention this temple complex. According to the Archaeological Survey of India, these inscriptions can be attributed to the Nolamba dynasty ruler Nolambadiraja and the Rashtrakuta emperor Govinda III, and they date from c. 806 and 810 CE. Copper plate inscriptions found about 10 kilometers away near Chikkaballapur refer to the wife of Bana Vidhyadhara making a gift to the temple. These are indirect references, as they do not specifically mention either of the two large twin temples. Based on architecture and iconography, the Bhoganandiswara and the Arunachaleswara temples are dated to no later than the 10th-century and no earlier than the 9th-century.

The temple was later under the patronage of successive notable South Indian dynasties, and they have all contributed to the form that has survived into the modern era: the Ganga Dynasty, the Hoysala Empire and the Vijayanagara Empire.

We know that the dham was established by Adi Shankara, whom the colonials dated to 800CE because of the Sandracottus sheet anchor! But it is increasingly becoming apparent that they were off in their estimates by some 2000 years. Adi Shankara would be around 1800 BCE. The mutts was established in his lifetime, and while he preferred to spend time in the Badrinath mutt, he travelled extensively, and is supposed to have attained mahasamadhi at Kedarnath.

So 1800 BCE is a good guess, but not necessarily the whole of the present structure of the temple. Probably the gopuram is the oldest. The structure in front of the gopuram is clearly of a different period, when the number of pilgrims and the inclement weather prompted the need for more covered space.

What is the name of the temple that has a special significance for Karnataka?

The Pranaveshwara temple at Talagunda (Shikaripura taluk, Shimoga) has special significance to Karnataka for the following reasons:

  1. The Pravanesvara temple here is a small square shaped simple temple with a sanctum (garbhagriha) and sukanasi (vestibule). In the sanctum it houses a Tall Shiva Linga on a bhadra pitha. This Pranaveshwar linga of Talagunda is the most ancient Shivalinga of Karnataka.
  2. The temple premises has the Talagonda pillar with inscription: This inscription is written in the Kannada script of those days - the box-headed Kadamba characters. The language of the inscription is poetic Sanskrit. It was written Kubja - the court poet of the Kadamba king Santivarman.
  3. It tells the story of Mayura Sharma - the person who established Kadamba dynasty - the first indigenous dynasty of Karnataka that we know. According to this inscription, Mayurasharma went to Kanchi the capital of the Pallavas to pursue his Vedic studies accompanied by his guru and grandfather Veerasharma. Kanchi was an important Ghatikasthana - or centre of learning during those days. In Kanchi, he was humiliated by a Pallava horseman and in this enrages Mayurasharma. He gives up his Brahminical studies and takes up the sword to avenge his insult. The Kadamba kingdom was born out of this successful rebellion of the Brahmanas against the Kshatriya power of the Pallavas of Kanchi. The inscription briefly describes how he slowly established the Kadamba dynasty and later even the Pallavas began to respect him.
  4. This inscription gives evidence for the existence of a Shiva temple in Talagunda and for Shiva worship prior to 450 AD. It also describes certain cultural values prevalent in the 5th century AD in India such as the mention of "music”, and Lakshmi as goddess of wealth.
  5. In 2013-14, the ASI conducted excavations in the Pranaveshwara temple at Talagunda. The excavations unearthed some old brick structures which are considered to belong to the older period temple built by Satavahanas around 2nd/3rd century AD. The Kadambas later modified the temple in stone and added additional structures. The north side balustrade has an inscription that is provisionally dated to around 370 AD. This inscription contains seven lines of Brahmi script written left to right in a slightly slanting manner. It is a dual language inscription with Kannada and Sanskrit words. If the dating is confirmed to 370 AD, it would make it the oldest Kannada inscription, predating the Halmidi inscription by almost 80 years.

Which is the oldest temple in Karnataka?

Madhukeshwara Temple at Banavasi, Sirsi taluk , Uttara Kannada district is probably the oldest temple in Karnataka.

Banavasi is very old place, it was also called as Vaijayanthipura in ancient times.

Huan Tsang and Alberuni have mentioned this place in their works. Kannada poet Pampa had lived here.

Kadamba dynasty which is called as the first Kannada Empire, started ruling from 345 AD. They considered Madhukeshwara as their kula devata, hence this temple precedes 3rd century.

It was originally built by Shatavahanas, Kadambas developed it and later was expanded by Chalukyas and Hoysalas.

It is dedicated to Lord Shiva. Here, one can see Linga in the color of honey and hence the name Madhukeshwara, madhu meaning Honey in Kannada and Sanskrit.

The east facing temple has shrines of Mahisasuramardhini, Ganesha, Nandi statue, and an ornamented shikara. The other temples found in the complex are dedicated to Parvati, Veerbhadreshwara, Narasimha, and Basavalingeshwara.

The precinct is full of sculptures taking different forms of deities placed in smaller temples of the courtyard. You can also Naga sculpture with an inscription in Brahmi and Prakrit.

There is a Nandi statue placed in Nritya Manatpa. It is about 7 feet huge and it is positioned in a way that it looks Shiva with the left eye and Parvathi with the right one.

Banavasi was the first capital of Karnataka.

Ending this answer with Pampa’s quote about Banavasi.

ಮಱದುಂಬಿಯಾಗಿ ಮೇಣ್ ಕೋಗಿಲೆಯಾಗಿ ಪುಟ್ಟುವುದು ನಂದನದೊಳ್ ವನವಾಸಿ ದೇಶದೊಳ್|

Translation in English -

It is a virtue to be born in Banavasi as a human being. If not as a human being, then one should be born at least as a bee or a cuckoo in the garden of Banavasi.

Indian Railways allow for the booking of Special trains for a

Why are old South Indian temples so rich while old North Indian temples look devastated?

It looks devastated because it is devastated. Many of the temples and other structures in North India were destroyed during the Islamic invasions and the subsequent Mughal rule. The Vijayanagara Empire in the Southern parts of the Country stood as a bulwark against these barbarians and as a result it escaped the kind of destruction that the North was subject to. The Somnath Temple alone was destroyed and rebuilt 17 times. This is also the reason why the “real” Indian culture is more prevalent in the South. The North became more conservative as Islamic influence seeped into the lives and culture of the land. The Islamic rulers were ruthless and their goal was to convert everyone to Islam. They demonstrated this by destroying temples and other monuments. They also carried out forceful conversions. The Mughal Empire was the Medieval version of the modern day ISIS and other Islamic extremists. ISIS recently destroyed the ancient structures of Syria and Iraq which were a testament to their non-Islamic history. Islamic extremists also destroyed several ancient Buddhist structures in Afghanistan. A similar story unfolded several centuries back in India resulting in the destruction of many of our glorious monuments.

Which is the oldest Hindu temple which still exists?

The Kanchi Kailasanathar Temple

This temple is located in Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu, India. Kanchi Kailasanathar is a Hindu temple in the Dravidian architectural style. It is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is known for its historical importance. The temple was built from 685-705 AD by a Rajasimha ruler of the Pallava Dynasty.

It is one of the earliest structural temples and the largest one built by the Pallavas.

It is of stone-built architecture unlike the rock-cut architecture built into hallowed caves or carved into rock outcrops as in Mahabalipuram. The tall gopuram (tower) is to the left and the temple complex is to the right. The temple's foundations are made of granite, which could withstand the weight of the temple, while the superstructure, including the carvings, are all made of sandstone.

Facts About Kanchi Kailasanathar Temple

  1. The most famous Brihadeshwara Temple in Thanjavur is inspired by Kailasanathar Temple.
  2. A passage is there inside the shrine. One has to crawl inside the passage and climb several steps to reach the exit. It is believed that this passage is symbolic of life and death.

Kanchipuram, one of India’s oldest continuously inhabited cities is often called the land of a thousand temples, and beautiful temples are the crowning glory of the magnificent city. If you are visiting Chennai don’t miss this.

Tips for the Temple visit

  • It is around 70 kilometres from Chennai.
  • Temple is open from 6 AM -12 PM and then 4 PM-9 PM
  • It is a very photogenic temple. Thankfully photography is permitted, except inside the sanctum.

Going by the way it is patronized and visited, including revenues from people staying at the huge temple complex, for certain, (I think) it must be the Sree Manjunatheshwara Swamy temple at Dharmasthala. No doubt, Udupi, Murudeshwara, Chamundeshwari at Mysuru as well as the Shri Nanjundeshwara swamy at Chamarajanagara are highly patronized, I think it is the Manjunatheshwara temple at Dharmasthala that is leading in revenues, though, as compared to Udupi or Chamundeshwari, I have personally seen huge crowds at Shri Nanjundeshwara temple in Chamarajanagara. These are purely my personal views based on my observations. I have been fortunate and blessed enough to visit four of the above five temples, excepting Sree Murudeshwara. I also feel that Sree Virupaksha at Hampi is a highly patronized temple, but I think it must be getting comparably lesser crowds because it is not located in the Bengaluru-Mysuru belt like Nanjundeshwara or Chamundeshwari, or in the Mangalore belt like Sree Manjunatha or Udupi Krishna temples, which are in the more populous areas.

What is the significance of Sarpasamskara at Kukke Shri Subrahmanya Temple in Karnataka?

Sarpa Samaskara is a pooja done for all those individuals who have Sarpa/Naga/Kala Sarpa Dosha or affliction caused by snakes in their horoscopes at Kukke Subramanya temple .

There may be instances where the person who is performing this might have caused harm to snakes/killed them unknowningly in the current or previous birth or their ancestors would have done this and ignored which consequently affects the second generation of the family generally or depends on the family tree which is how Sarpa Dosha is caused.

Individuals suffering with this might have a delay in getting married, delayed ach

Sarpa Samaskara is a pooja done for all those individuals who have Sarpa/Naga/Kala Sarpa Dosha or affliction caused by snakes in their horoscopes at Kukke Subramanya temple .

There may be instances where the person who is performing this might have caused harm to snakes/killed them unknowningly in the current or previous birth or their ancestors would have done this and ignored which consequently affects the second generation of the family generally or depends on the family tree which is how Sarpa Dosha is caused.

Individuals suffering with this might have a delay in getting married, delayed achievement of their goals, marital challenges if they are married etc.

Male members might perform it themselves or are usually insisted to perform provided they have a deceased parent(one of the instances where the person doesn’t have a father can do it for themslves or on behalf of their children or relatives who have been inflicted with Naga Dosha) .

Several noted celebrities like Sachin Tendulkar,Ravi Shastri and the current Home Minister of India, Amit Shah ji have been here to perform the same.

It is a pooja which takes 2 days and the individuals and their families performing this have to stay committed till it’s very end which is a mandate given by the temple to see it’s fruitful results.

Day1 : Sarpa Samaskara Pooja

i) To start off with , You have to take a holy dip or bathe in the beautiful Kumaradhara river before you move on to have a Darshan of the deity early morning. Kumaradhara river is absolutely a beauty amidst Kumaraparvata Peak where the water flowing in the river joins Netravati river at Upinangadi and eventually flows into the Arabian Sea.

The experience of taking a dip is just amazing. Lovely clean water (atleast now) and a treat to see many fishes flowing past in the river.

ii) You have to reach Sarpasamaskara Pooja Hall at Adi Subramanya Temple by 8:30 (on dot since the pooja performed is on time and quick so any kind of delay and you will miss out on the procedures suggested by the temple guide. You cannot take food outside the two days which is must and should rule to be followed. Though you can have light fruits etc. but if you can fast ,it’s even good.

iii) Once you reach the venue at the specified time ,if you are a brahmin, there will be pujaris to guide you with the ritual procedure else if you are not a brahmin and of a different caste/religion(also saw certain Muslims and Christians attend this to ward off the evil effect in their own families), the pujaris themselves will perform sankalpa on your behalf and the procedures to be done as a part of the pooja which is inclusive of the pooja amount of 3200 charged by the temple management.

The first day of pooja usually involves samhara(to ensure proper burial rites for the deceased snake) as well as giving a new lease of the life to the snake which is best explained by the temple pujaris while performing it.

iv) The first part of pooja starts at 8:30 AM and ends by 11:30 AM .The pujari will give you instructions for the second day (which begins at 5:30 AM in the morning next day) post which you will have to take lunch and dinner for that day at the bhojanshala of the same temple.

Day 2 : Sarpa Samaskara with Naga Pratisthapana

You have to be at the same venue at 5:30 AM where the next set of rituals will start and the pujaris will instruct on how it is to be done. The second day will be about preparing Pind Daan/Pinda Daana for the deceased snake and also a way of ensuring the sin of killing of snake does not affect the ancestors as well . This will be usually done by 7:30 AM after which you will have to take breakfast provided by temple management.

The next ritual is Naga Pratisthapana meaning establishment or replacing the dead snake with a new one. This is a pooja usually done at 12 noon in the main temple of Kukke Subramanya where the pujari performs the pooja as a final step of all the Samaskara pooja. This will usually end within a hour post which is followed by lunch.

Best part of Sarpa Samaskara pooja.

  1. Well planned , well organised by the temple management sincerely unlike what we see in Kalahasti where everything is usually commercial.
  2. The lunch ,dinner(1st day) and breakfast(2nd day) provided by the temple and the dining hall is the same for everyone irrespective of the caste/religion though the last lunch on second day might differ (for brahmins lunch is usually at Sringeri Mutt).
  3. You see people from all walks of life facing their problems in life due to this almost everyday not just for one specific season.
  4. The temple as a result of the 3rd point earns well but can surely use the funds to develop and improve the facilities for the devotees travelling from various parts of the countries to perform this,hence crowd management is the only challenge the temple faces.
  5. It is usually advised to return home immediately without planning a temple trip elsewere post completion of Pooja.

Hope that helps.

How old is Mumbadevi Temple in Mumbai?

The Mumbadevi temple is six centuries old. The first Mumbadevi temple was situated at Bori Bunder, and is believed to have been destroyed between 1739 and 1770. After the destruction a new temple was erected at the same place at Bhuleshwar.

All are built by same empire. The Hoysalas.

But they have differences for some one who has keen eyes and wanting to learn more about architecture.

These temples are built on different time. So you can see by seeing one by one in order how the hoysala architecture evolved.

How old is Madurai meenaksiamman temple?

Many historical evidence have been found dating back from early AD.But,These evidences were not enough to come to a conclusion because Meenakshi amman temple was almost completely destroyed following a Islamic invasion by a muslim conqueror, Malik kafur who is the slave-general of Alaudin Khilji in 1310.There are also many evidence in Sangam tamil literature too. Thirugnanasambandar ,the Hindu Saint has mentioned the temple in his songs which go back to early 12th century AD.The temple restored its glory in 14th century when hindu kings came back to power. Thirumalai nayakar has contributed a lot in the reconstruction of the temple.And It is said that the great poet thiruvalluvar’s mind blowing work Thirukural was screened in the sangapalagai in meenakshi amman kovil. Why are Karnataka temples famous?

For their intricate sculptures. By nature the Kannadigas are very humble and highly devoted people to God.

The upkeep and maintananceof the temple are perfect. They perform all rituals smoothly.

The heritage is preserved exceptionally well .

The Kannada Brahmins get their due respect from the society.Luckily they have not encouraged people who make money by professing atheism as in Tamil Nadu..

Adi Shankaran appointed Kannada priests to do the daily rituals in Kedarnath and Badrinath. That rule is being followed to this day. Deep South at the famous Tiruchendur Temple, Karnataka Brhamins are the c

For their intricate sculptures. By nature the Kannadigas are very humble and highly devoted people to God.

The upkeep and maintananceof the temple are perfect. They perform all rituals smoothly.

The heritage is preserved exceptionally well .

The Kannada Brahmins get their due respect from the society.Luckily they have not encouraged people who make money by professing atheism as in Tamil Nadu..

Adi Shankaran appointed Kannada priests to do the daily rituals in Kedarnath and Badrinath. That rule is being followed to this day. Deep South at the famous Tiruchendur Temple, Karnataka Brhamins are the chief priests. Only they have the right to touch the main idols .

So traditionally due non corruption, due respect to fellow human beings and the great regard for cleaniness, Karnataka temples are famous .
